0.title: Other Data used by the software are explicitly identified and traceable with a persistent identifier (DOI) when available

1.title: Argo papers and DOIs are referenced in the software metadata

2.title: The software has been presented to the Argo community (e.g. Data Management Team meeting)

3.title: The software documentation includes usage guidelines and examples

4.title: The software uses an open-source programming language (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_open-source_programming_languages)

5.title: The software uses a programming language adopted within the Argo community (e.g. Matlab, Python, R, Java, Julia)

6.title: The codebase includes comments and is documented following referenced standards (e.g. numpy style docstrings in Python)

7.title: The codebase is formatted following referenced standards (e.g. black in Python)

8.title: The project is hosted on a web-based developer platform (e.g., GitHub or GitLab).

9.title: The software provides a clear description of its dependencies

10.title: The software is released under an open-source license (include an open-source LICENSE file with the license content to the codebase)

11.title: The project includes a basic documentation (e.g. a README file)

12.title: The software documentation has an API reference section automatically generated

13.title: The software documentation is hosted on the web

14.title: The software documentation includes installation guidelines

15.title: The software includes continuous integration and unit testing

18.title: The software is distributed via well-known services (e.g., pip or conda for Python)

19.title: The software has a unique persistent identifier (e.g. DOI from paper or Zenodo, SWHID)

21.title: Argo Data used by the software are traceable with a persistent identifier (Argo GDAC DOI or snapshot DOIs)

22.title: Other Data used by the software should be accessible online

23.title: Data produced by the software respect Argo file formats and conventions wherever relevant (e.g. NetCDF CF-1.7)

24.title: Metadata produced by the software follow Argo conventions (as in reference tables provided by the NVS server)

25.title: The software uses the Argo vocabulary server (to enforce conventions as defined in Argo reference tables)

26.title: The software documentation and codebase are written in English

28.title: The methodology implemented by the software has been presented to the Argo community (e.g. Data Management Team meeting)

29.title: A version control tool is used to manage the project (e.g., Git)

30.title: Argo Data accessed remotely by the software are retrieved from an official GDAC server (http, ftp, s3 servers)

31.title: The project is hosted on an Argo developer platform (eg: github/euroargodev, github/ArgoDMQC, github/ArgoRTQC or any other project or institute level organisation)

32.title: The project includes a README file

33.title: The project includes a LICENSE file

35.title: The project has multiple collaborators from the Argo community

36.title: Each collaborator is clearly identified within the project

38.title: Issues or bugs are managed through the development web platform (e.g., GitHub or GitLab issues)

40.title: Issues or bugs are explicitly referencing the concerned Argo mission (e.g. core, deep, BGC, ...) or component (e.g. trajectories, decoding,...)

41.title: Every significant change within the code is managed through a pull (or merge) request

46.title: The project includes a CONTRIBUTING file

47.title: The software documentation includes the list of operating systems and environments supported

48.title: The software documentation includes the definition of the execution environment supported

51.title: The project clearly list all software identifiers in the README file (e.g. DOI, SWHID)

52.title: The software is registered in at least one public software registry (e.g., Zenodo, Seanoe, Research Software Directory)

53.title: The software is registered in an Argo software registry (e.g. AST and Argo-BGC dedicated webpages)

56.title: The codebase is designed with modular components to facilitate reuse, testing and maintenance

57.title: The codebase is "consistent", i.e. it follows consistent naming conventions, coding styles, and design patterns throughout the software

58.title: The codebase includes comments and is documented to explain the purpose and functionality of each module, class, and function

59.title: The project defines expected standards of conduct when engaging in the project (e.g. includes a CODE_OF_CONDUCT file to the codebase)

60.title: Argo Data accessed locally by the software must be assumed to be organised following the GDAC folder structure

61.title: Argo Meta-Data accessed remotely by the software are retrieved from an official Argo sources (GDAC ftp, GDAC https, NVS, SparQL, STAC)

62.title: The project allows any user to submit an issue or bug report and ease the process (e.g. provide list of labels, issue templates)

feedback.message: Critical: Improve your Argo Compliance practices to reach the next level
